He frequently gravitated toward genre material—war films, thrillers, and later horror and science-fiction projects—where his serious demeanor could anchor otherwise outlandish plots. He appeared in features such as "4D Man" and "Empire of the Ants" as well as TV movies that took advantage of his ability to project gravitas, whether as a villain, a conflicted professional, or a man confronting extraordinary circumstances. While he rarely headlined major studio blockbusters, he became a familiar and reliable presence in character roles across film and television.

Robert Lansing.header: Steady Television Presence and Character Actor
Robert Lansing.text: Through the 1970s and 1980s, Lansing remained a regular presence on American television. He had recurring or starring roles in series such as "The Man Who Never Was," "Kung Fu: The Legend Continues" (in which he appeared late in his career), and numerous guest shots on shows like "The Twilight Zone," "Alfred Hitchcock Presents," "Bonanza," "Mission: Impossible," and others. Casting directors often turned to him for roles that required a believable figure of command—police chiefs, intelligence officials, judges, or military officers—because he could convey authority without resorting to bluster. His deep voice and calm, deliberate cadence made even exposition-heavy dialogue feel grounded, and he was equally capable of playing sympathetic mentors or morally ambiguous antagonists.

Off-screen, Lansing was known as a serious craftsman rather than a celebrity driven by publicity. He married twice, first to actress Emily McLaughlin and later to Gari Hardy, and had a son, Robert Jr. Colleagues often described him as professional and focused on set, with a dry sense of humor that sometimes surfaced between takes. He maintained ties to the theater throughout his life, returning to stage work when opportunities arose. While he never cultivated the kind of public persona that dominated tabloids or talk shows, he built quiet respect within the acting community as a dependable, thoughtful performer who brought his full attention to every role, whether in a low-budget genre piece or a prestige television drama.

In his later years, Lansing continued to act, taking on guest roles and character parts that suited his age and experience. He appeared in episodes of series like "Kung Fu: The Legend Continues" and other 1990s television projects, often playing seasoned authority figures or mentors. He died on October 23, 1994, in New York City, at the age of sixty-six, from lung cancer. His passing marked the end of a career that had spanned four decades and multiple eras of television history, from early black-and-white dramas to color network series and syndicated genre shows.

Robert Lansing.header: Legacy Across Crime, War, and Science Fiction
Robert Lansing.text: Robert Lansing’s legacy rests on the solidity and nuance he brought to roles that might otherwise have been one-dimensional. Whether as Detective Steve Carella, General Frank Savage, or the enigmatic Gary Seven, he created characters who felt fully inhabited: disciplined men with inner lives, moral codes, and the capacity for doubt. For Star Trek fans, his single appearance as Gary Seven has remained a source of fascination, inspiring novels, comics, and speculation about the series that might have been. More broadly, his work across crime dramas, war stories, and science fiction has secured him a lasting place as one of television’s quintessential strong, serious leading men—an actor whose presence alone could make a story feel larger, weightier, and more real.

Susanna Thompson.header: San Diego Roots and the Road to the Stage
Susanna Thompson.text: Susanna Thompson was born on January 27, 1958, in San Diego, California, growing up in a part of the United States that gave her easy access to both the Pacific coast and the thriving arts communities of Southern California. From an early age she gravitated toward storytelling and performance, eventually pursuing formal training in drama at San Diego State University. There she not only developed the craft and discipline that would sustain a long career, but also forged a connection to the academic world that remained part of her life; her future husband, Martin Katz, would become a professor at the same institution. By the time she graduated, Thompson had paired classical acting technique with an understated, grounded presence that would become her trademark on stage and screen.

Susanna Thompson.header: Stage Foundations and an Actor’s Craft
Susanna Thompson.text: Before most viewers ever saw her in film or on television, Thompson spent significant time honing her skills in theater. She earned critical attention in regional productions, winning a Dramatic Award for her performance as Luisa in "A Shayna Maidel" and later receiving a Best Actress nomination from the San Diego Critics Circle for "Agnes of God." These roles demanded emotional range, precise timing, and a willingness to sit with difficult subject matter, all qualities that would echo throughout her later screen work. The physical training she undertook—especially in aikido and stage combat—also became part of her professional toolkit, allowing her to inhabit characters who could be physically authoritative without sacrificing nuance. For Thompson, the stage was not a stepping stone so much as a proving ground, one that shaped the way she approached every later part.

Thompson’s film and television career accelerated in the early 1990s, as she began landing guest roles on series and supporting parts in feature films. On television she made appearances on shows like "Silk Stalkings," "Civil Wars," and "L.A. Law," gradually building a reputation as a performer who could anchor an episode with quiet intensity. In cinema she turned up in projects such as "Little Giants," "Ghosts of Mississippi," "Random Hearts," and "Dragonfly," often playing characters whose emotional reality helped ground stories that mixed melodrama, romance, or the supernatural. While these roles rarely put her at the center of large-scale franchises, they demonstrated her ability to make even limited screen time feel specific and lived-in, a skill that would prove crucial when she stepped into the heightened worlds of science fiction.

Susanna Thompson.header: A Familiar Face Across the Star Trek Franchise
Susanna Thompson.text: Long before she ever became the Borg Queen, Thompson had already woven herself into the fabric of Star Trek. She first appeared in "Star Trek: The Next Generation" as Varel, a Romulan scientist in the episode "The Next Phase," bringing a quiet, intellectual dignity to a character caught between duty and curiosity. She returned to The Next Generation as the inmate Jaya in "Frame of Mind," inhabiting a more unsettling environment that blurred the line between sanity and constructed reality. Thompson then moved into "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine" as Dr. Lenara Kahn in the episode "Rejoined," playing a joined Trill whose rekindled love for Jadzia Dax sparked one of the franchise’s most discussed early depictions of same-sex romance on American television. By the time she accepted the role of the Borg Queen, she had already portrayed three distinct characters across the Star Trek universe, each with its own emotional and thematic weight.

Among Thompson’s pre–Borg Queen Trek roles, Lenara Kahn in "Rejoined" stands out for its cultural impact. The episode centers on Lenara’s reunion with Jadzia Dax, whose previous host had been married to Lenara’s former host. The Trill taboo against rekindling past host relationships provides the narrative obstacle, but the staging of the romance—between two women in their current incarnations—placed the story firmly in the realm of queer representation. Thompson’s performance is restrained, full of small hesitations and carefully controlled emotion, which makes the relationship feel genuine rather than treated as a gimmick. The much-discussed kiss between Lenara and Jadzia is charged not by shock value but by the sense that both characters are torn between their culture’s rules and their own deep attachment. Thompson’s ability to ground that conflict helped make the episode a touchstone for many viewers seeking more inclusive storytelling within Star Trek.

Susanna Thompson.header: Becoming the Borg Queen on Voyager
Susanna Thompson.text: Thompson’s most prominent Star Trek role came when she assumed the mantle of the Borg Queen on "Star Trek: Voyager." Introduced in the feature film "Star Trek: First Contact," the Queen had already been played memorably by Alice Krige, but Voyager needed an actor who could carry the character across multiple episodes while interacting extensively with the series regulars. Thompson stepped into that challenge in the feature-length episode "Dark Frontier" and later in the two-parter "Unimatrix Zero." Her version of the Queen combined a cold, analytical intelligence with flashes of near-maternal possessiveness toward Seven of Nine, conveying both the seductive promise and the chilling control of the Borg Collective. While the Borg Queen has been portrayed by several performers across film and television, Thompson’s recurring presence on Voyager gave her one of the most substantial on-screen runs in the role, and for many fans her interpretation is inseparable from the character’s television legacy.

Susanna Thompson.header: A Different Face of the Collective
Susanna Thompson.text: In Voyager, Thompson’s Borg Queen is less a distant monarch and more an intimate interrogator, constantly closing the physical and emotional distance between herself and Seven of Nine. She uses a low, measured vocal cadence, balanced with sudden spikes of intensity, to sell the idea that the Queen can shift from apparent tenderness to lethal resolve in a heartbeat. The way Thompson carries herself—often still, with small, precise movements—suggests a being who has no need to waste energy, because the power of an entire Collective stands behind her. When she does erupt into anger or step physically closer to her adversaries, those moments land with greater impact. Her performance emphasizes that the Borg’s horror is not just technological; it is psychological, rooted in a mind that understands what individual beings fear and desire and can weaponize both.

Susanna Thompson.header: Beyond the Collective: Once and Again and Arrow
Susanna Thompson.text: While Star Trek fans often first think of Thompson as a Borg Queen or as Lenara Kahn, her career encompasses a wide range of grounded, contemporary roles. On the acclaimed drama "Once and Again," she portrayed Karen Sammler, navigating divorce, parenthood, and the complexities of blended families with a performance that stayed rooted in small gestures and lived-in emotion. Years later she would become a central figure in the DC Comics–inspired series "Arrow" as Moira Queen, mother to Oliver Queen. As Moira, Thompson played a woman who loved her children yet kept dangerous secrets, standing at the intersection of political power, corporate machination, and family loyalty. These roles demonstrated her ability to hold the center of an ensemble, balancing vulnerability with moral ambiguity in ways that made her characters feel truthful even when their circumstances were heightened.

Thompson’s filmography underscores her versatility. In addition to genre projects like "Dragonfly"—where she played a wife whose death and possible supernatural messages drive the film’s mystery—she has appeared in legal dramas, medical series, procedurals, and high-concept genre shows such as "Kings," "NCIS," and "Timeless." She slips comfortably between supporting and leading roles, sometimes anchoring a series arc, other times reinforcing a story as a guest star whose character must feel fully realized in a single hour. This breadth of work speaks to an actor who treats each part, no matter its size, as an opportunity to explore a specific human perspective. Whether she is playing a queen, a scientist, a politician, or a parent, there is a throughline of care in how she listens, reacts, and allows silence to carry as much meaning as dialogue.

A recurring thread in discussions of Thompson’s work is her physical discipline. Training in aikido and stage combat did more than allow her to perform stylized confrontations; it informed the way she occupies space. As the Borg Queen, she can convey menace simply by stepping a fraction closer to the camera, tilting her head, or letting a pause stretch just long enough to become uncomfortable. As Moira Queen or Karen Sammler, that same control translates into a composed posture that occasionally cracks, revealing the emotional cost of the choices her characters make. This attention to physical detail gives her performances a layered quality: the audience can sense what the character is trying not to show, which makes the eventual moments of vulnerability or rage feel earned rather than sudden.

Susanna Thompson.header: A Lasting Imprint on Star Trek
Susanna Thompson.text: Within the Star Trek franchise, Thompson occupies a rare position. Few performers have played as many distinct roles across multiple series, and fewer still have anchored episodes that carry such thematic weight. From the ethical and emotional dilemmas of "Rejoined" to the psychological warfare of "Dark Frontier" and "Unimatrix Zero," her characters sit at key crossroads in the ongoing conversation about identity, choice, and connection that runs through Star Trek. For many viewers, she is not just one incarnation of the Borg Queen but a versatile performer whose work helped expand what Star Trek could say about love, autonomy, and the cost of belonging. Her contributions, spread across decades and several shows, ensure that her presence in the Star Trek universe feels larger than any single character—continuing to resonate whenever fans revisit the episodes she helped define.

Teri Garr.text: Terry Ann Garr was born on December 11, 1944, and grew up in an entertainment family that moved between the East Coast and Los Angeles before settling in North Hollywood. Her father, Eddie Garr, was a vaudeville performer, comedian, and actor; her mother, Phyllis, worked as a dancer, Rockette, wardrobe mistress, and studio costumier. Surrounded by rehearsal halls, costumes, and backstage stories, Teri absorbed show business as a natural part of everyday life. She studied ballet and other forms of dance as a child and teenager, discovering early that performance was not just a family tradition but also the place where she felt most at home.

Teri Garr.header: From Dancer to Elvis Movies and TV Variety Shows
Teri Garr.text: Garr began her career in the 1960s as a dancer, working in youth-oriented films and television shows choreographed by David Winters, whom she met during a road company production of West Side Story. She appeared as a background dancer in beach-party movies, musical specials, and variety series like Shindig!, Hullabaloo, and Movin’ with Nancy, as well as the concert film The T.A.M.I. Show. Her most notable early work came as an uncredited dancer in a string of Elvis Presley films, including Viva Las Vegas and other popular entries, where she learned the rhythms of film production from the edges of the frame. These jobs didn’t yet showcase her comic acting, but they gave her professional discipline and a foothold in Hollywood.

Teri Garr.header: Acting Classes, New York, and Early Speaking Roles
Teri Garr.text: Determined to move beyond dancing, Garr studied acting at the Actors Studio and the Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute, sharpening her craft and learning how to channel her natural comic instincts into character work. She landed a small but memorable speaking role in the Monkees’ surreal 1968 movie Head, delivering an over-the-top line as a frontier woman dying of snakebite. Around the same time, she began accumulating television credits in series like Batman, The Andy Griffith Show, Mayberry R.F.D., and It Takes a Thief. These early roles were brief but varied, allowing her to experiment with different tones—quirky, earnest, sarcastic—and to prove that she could be funny while still grounding a character in reality.

Teri Garr.header: Roberta Lincoln and a Star Trek Breakthrough
Teri Garr.text: Garr’s first substantial television role came in 1968, when she played Roberta Lincoln in the Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth.” The character, a smart, mod-era secretary who stumbles into the world of time-traveling agent Gary Seven, allowed Garr to combine physical comedy, quick timing, and a very contemporary sense of skepticism. Roberta’s confusion, indignation, and eventual courage gave the story much of its charm, and the episode was designed as a backdoor pilot for a potential spin-off built around Gary Seven and Roberta’s future adventures. Although that series was never produced, “Assignment: Earth” gave Garr a showcase that fans remembered for decades and marked a turning point from anonymous dancer to recognizable comic actress.

Teri Garr.header: Young Frankenstein, The Conversation, and 1970s Film Work
Teri Garr.text: The 1970s brought Garr a series of film roles that moved her into the front rank of screen comedians. In 1974 she appeared in Francis Ford Coppola’s thriller The Conversation and, the same year, in Mel Brooks’s Young Frankenstein as Inga, the wide-eyed but resourceful assistant to Gene Wilder’s Dr. Frankenstein. With her exuberant delivery, impeccable timing, and willingness to commit fully to Brooks’s affectionate parody, she helped make Young Frankenstein a comedy classic. She followed these successes with roles in Oh, God! as John Denver’s bemused wife, in Steven Spielberg’s Close Encounters of the Third Kind as the increasingly frightened spouse of Richard Dreyfuss’s character, and in The Black Stallion as a caring but overwhelmed mother. These performances showed that she could move between broad comedy and grounded domestic drama, often playing women trying to cope with husbands on the brink of obsession or transformation.

Garr reached a career peak in the early 1980s. In Sydney Pollack’s Tootsie, she played Sandy Lester, a struggling actress whose best friend and acting coach disguises himself as a woman to land a soap-opera role. Garr’s portrayal of Sandy—neurotic, hopeful, wounded, and very funny—earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress and a BAFTA nomination. She followed this with a starring role opposite Michael Keaton in Mr. Mom, playing a working mother juggling career pressures while her laid-off husband learns to run the household, and with a lead in Francis Ford Coppola’s musical romance One from the Heart. In Martin Scorsese’s After Hours she added an offbeat edge to a darkly comic portrait of downtown New York. Across these films, Garr became known for portraying women with sharp wit and emotional honesty, often reacting to the chaos the men in their lives created.

Alongside her film work, Garr was a familiar face on American television. She had recurring or guest roles on series such as McCloud, M*A*S*H, The Bob Newhart Show, The Odd Couple, Maude, Barnaby Jones, and, later, Friends, where she played Phoebe Buffay’s birth mother, Phoebe Abbott. She hosted Saturday Night Live multiple times and became legendary for her loose, unscripted banter on The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson and Late Night with David Letterman, often trading rapid-fire jokes with the hosts. Her conversational wit and willingness to play along with absurd setups made her a favorite guest; for many viewers, these late-night appearances were as memorable as her film roles.

Teri Garr.header: Voice Work, Stage Roles, and Later Projects
Teri Garr.text: Garr continued to diversify her work in the 1990s and 2000s. She voiced Mary McGinnis, the mother of the future Batman, in the animated series Batman Beyond, and appeared in projects like Dumb and Dumber, Ready to Wear (Prêt-à-Porter), Michael, Casper Meets Wendy, Dick, Ghost World, and various independent films. On stage she joined ensembles for The Vagina Monologues and other productions, bringing her comic instincts to live performance even as screen roles became less frequent. Her career, spanning from go-go dancing in Elvis musicals to Oscar-nominated comedy, illustrated both range and resilience.

Teri Garr.header: Multiple Sclerosis, Health Challenges, and Advocacy
Teri Garr.text: After years of unexplained symptoms, Garr was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in the late 1990s and publicly disclosed her condition in 2002. Rather than retreat from view, she became an advocate for others living with MS, serving as a National Ambassador for the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and chairing its Women Against MS program. She used her humor in speeches and interviews to demystify the disease, emphasizing that a diagnosis did not erase a person’s identity or capacity for joy. In 2006 she survived a ruptured brain aneurysm and worked hard to recover speech and mobility, later discussing the experience candidly in public appearances.

Garr published her memoir, Speedbumps: Flooring It Through Hollywood, in 2005, weaving together stories of show business, family, illness, and survival with the self-deprecating wit that characterized her interviews. As MS symptoms progressed, she gradually stepped back from acting, effectively retiring around 2011. She died in Los Angeles on October 29, 2024, at the age of seventy-nine. Her legacy spans several generations of audiences: Star Trek fans remember her as Roberta Lincoln; filmgoers cherish her in Young Frankenstein, Close Encounters, and Tootsie; and television viewers recall her as one of the most quick-witted, game talk-show guests of the late-night era. Across all of these, Teri Garr is remembered as a performer who made vulnerability funny, intelligence charming, and resilience look effortless.
